Award.AwardTitle: NRT-IGE: Data Science for the Built Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NRT-IGE: Data Science for the Built Environment

The availability of voluminous, high resolution data in both the spatial and temporal dimensions, coupled with increasingly fast, distributed computational resources offers enormous opportunities for tackling complex engineering and science challenges in urban settings. These data can also play an important role in interdisciplinary problem solving and have increasingly high value to multiple communities of scientists and engineers. However, research in the optimal instruction mechanisms to develop data science skills is still emerging. This is particularly true for engineering graduate students, who are a highly selected, technologically sophisticated population with the ability to quickly master material. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to the University of California-Davis will pilot, test, and compare modes of data science instruction. The testbed project will provide critical new information to inform the development of new learning platforms designed to cultivate robust computational, statistical, and data reasoning skills in engineering graduate students.

The project will implement a hybrid short-course approach that 1) bridges existing code camps and semester long classes, and 2) is coupled with a formal user group experience. A robust evaluation will be conducted to identify the individual effects of code camps, short courses, and users groups, as well as the effect of participating in combinations of experiences. In addition, learning gains, self-efficacy to engage in interdisciplinary studies that require data science principles, and career trajectories (including decisions to take additional coursework in data science and decisions to pursue interdisciplinary research and employment involving data science) will be examined. The project will generate new knowledge that addresses a particularly important gap in knowledge in terms of whether intense short-term learning experiences result in longer-term retention of skill development and computational reasoning. Findings on effectiveness of different modes of data science instruction in engineering will be broadly applicable to all data-enabled science and engineering fields.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative, and scalable models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The availability of voluminous, highly resolved data in both the spatial and temporal dimensions, coupled with increasingly fast, distributed computational resources, offers enormous opportunities for tackling complex engineering challenges in urban settings. Educating engineering graduate students in the production, use, and management of large data sets should be an integral part of engineering graduate training. The purpose of this research was to identify optimal modes of data science instruction that can significantly enhance engineering graduate students’ ability to learn and retain data science skills in an interdisciplinary setting.

As part of this grant, we evaluated the efficacy of using accelerated learning platforms (e.g., bootcamps) as a way of integrating data science skills development into graduate education training.  We conducted different combinations of accelerated learning experiences, including code camps and short courses, coupled with faculty-guided group study. We were specifically interested in how course delivery mechanisms could: 1) deliver a time-intensive experience that can be easily integrated into existing engineering graduate education; 2) enhance engineering training in data science skills; and 3) evaluate the degree to which interdisciplinary learning is retained throughout an engineering student’s graduate education.

We made two major, foundational insights. The first relates to interdisciplinarity and the second to interdisciplinarity in data science problems. One of the conundrums of interdisciplinary research is that it is critical for addressing modern problems, but our knowledge about the best way to train individuals to work in such settings, or how to build the antecedents to successful interdisciplinary collaboration is limited. We used three stages of analysis used to develop a measure of interdisciplinary self-efficacy: interaction, integration, and awareness. Our results strongly suggest that an individual’s awareness of the skills and knowledge they bring to interdisciplinary work, their confidence in being able to integrate both theory and methods, and self-efficacy around interpersonal interactions are essential components of interdisciplinary self-efficacy. We believe this exists independent of the data science training platform.

We also drew new insight on the relative effectiveness of bootcamp-like workshops and coursework in developing data science and interdisciplinary skills to identify the benefits and drawbacks of using these formats to increase the training opportunities available to students. We compared two formats of interdisciplinary data science training that supplement disciplinary graduate programs: two-day workshops and ten-week courses with the same instructor and similar content coverage. We expected to find larger data science skill gains in courses than in workshops, however we also hypothesized that distinct sets of graduate students would choose one training format over the other.  

We combined an assessment of data science skills in R, a survey of interdisciplinary self-efficacy, and focus group discussions to evaluate four implementations of data science training for 155 graduate student participants. Survey instruments were used to collect data before and after each training opportunity. Focus group transcripts were analyzed to explain quantitative findings and explore aspects of students’ experiences missed by other metrics. Our findings were mixed; however a few strong outcomes were noted.  Graduate students’ self-efficacy for interdisciplinary work improved without direct instruction through engagement in-group work in one ten-week course. Data science skills improved significantly even after two-day workshop training, but not as much as after ten-week courses. Our results also show that graduate students were agnostic in their selection of either the workshop and course format.  The workshop format shows promise for improving data science skills while also exposing graduate students to research problems and peers from different disciplines. Training without requiring collaborative work did not improve graduate students’ interdisciplinary self-efficacy. Students felt similarly satisfied with differing aspects of the two formats of training based on expectations for learning goals.

Our goal was to extend our understanding of how and which platforms can be used to teach data science. Succinctly stated, in this research we were able to identify that student knowledge is similar to, but less sticky, in short bursts teaching platforms when compared to traditional classroom settings. We have advanced understanding of how different learning platforms compare in terms of data science skills acquisition.
